docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You did a great service in highlighting the importance of mourning pregnancy losses (front page, Jan. 25). Regardless of the gestational age and circumstances of the pregnancy loss, many parents are confused about what to feel. It is common to experience a wide range of feelings. However, I was struck by the mention of ''overmourning.'' Because this loss can be so profound and unlike any other, it often takes a long time to process the feelings.
docs.abstract: Hillary Grill letter contends that Jan 25 article did great service in highlighting importance of mourning pregnancy losses

docs.lead_paragraph: ABOARD THE ENDEAVOR, at Sea, Dec. 22--The pride of a nation set sail in this ship last night as she began her voyage south with the New Zealand element of the Commonwealth Trans-Antarctic Expedition.
docs.abstract: Hillary group sails; unable to repair plane; plans to rendezvous with Brit group near Pole in last wk in Jan in attempt to traverse continent; Sullivan notes pub interest in venture, largely supported by pub subscription

docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Fields writes romance novels for a living, but she doesn't date much. At 26, Ms. Fields, a native New Yorker, seems as independent as her strong-willed heroines. She has leapt screaming from an airplane, traveled alone to Australia and New Zealand and published two novels with female protagonists -- a pirate and an explorer -- who don't adhere to the shrinking-violet conventions of the genre.
docs.abstract: Hillary Fields, a native New Yorker, writes romance novels, but she herself is shy and does not date much; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In November, 1966, Sir Edmund Hillary and Dr. Max Pearl were building a hospital near Mount Everest. Their wives came to visit them, bringing three little Hillaries and three little Pearls. This rugged holiday is the subject of Lady Hillary's new book.
docs.abstract: Hillary, Louise: A Yak for Christmas

docs.lead_paragraph: SOMEWHERE in the Himalayas this morning, slung racily with rucksacks, water bottles and map cases, there strides a leathery giant from the Antipodes, 6 foot 5, and tough as rawhide. His face is long and wrinkled, his feet enormous, and he eats like a trencherman.

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN a child lies suffering from illness, injury or grief, in a hospital, homeless shelter, refugee camp or even in the stillborn silence of a tiny coffin -- Hillary Roberts has them covered. Under her direction, volunteers make 15,000 blankets a year and send them to those in need of comfort. She started five years ago and now works with 3,700 New Jerseyans who, like her, want to help others.
docs.abstract: Article on Project Linus New Jersey Inc, founded by Hillary Roberts, whose 3,700 volunteers statewide make 15,000 blankets a year and send them to sick, injured, grieving, homeless or refugee children in US and abroad; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: SCOTT BASE, Antarctica, Jan., 13 -- We arrived on the Polar plateau on Oct. 31, having covered a total distance of 390 miles. But because of our westerly trend, we were still only ten miles nearer to the Pole than Scott Base.
docs.abstract: article on trip across S Polar plateau; illus

headline.main: TRACTORS PULLED HILLARY THROUGH; 'Faithful' Vehicles Overcame Perils in Final Trek From Plateau to South Pole SNOW RIDGES MASTERED High Winds, Bad Visibility Slowed Pace -- Crevasses Posed Major Obstacle TRACTORS PULLED HILLARY THROUGH
